patterns: What to do if I have a cut?
How do I treat a cut?
Which medicine should I apply for a cut?
What should I apply on a cut?
Cuts
How to stop bleeding from a cut?
How to clean a cut?
responses: Wash the cut thoroughly with clean water and mild soap to prevent infection. Apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth or sterile gauze for 1-2 minutes until bleeding stops. Apply a thin layer of petroleum jelly to keep the wound moist and promote healing. Cover the cut with a sterile bandage. Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen can help manage pain. If the bleeding is severe, or the wound is deep, seek immediate medical attention. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.**

patterns: How do you treat abrasions?
Do abrasions cause scars?
Abrasions
What to do if I have abrasions?
Which medicine should I apply for abrasions?
How do I cure abrasions?
How to clean an abrasion?
responses: Begin with washed hands. Gently clean the area with cool to lukewarm water and mild soap. Remove dirt or other particles from the wound using sterilized tweezers. For a mild scrape thatâ€™s not bleeding, leave the wound uncovered. If the wound is bleeding, use a clean cloth or bandage, and apply gentle pressure to the area to stop any bleeding. Cover a wound that bled with a thin layer of topical antibiotic ointment, like Bacitracin, or a sterile moisture barrier ointment, like Aquaphor. Cover it with a clean bandage or gauze. Gently clean the wound and change the ointment and bandage once per day. Watch the area for signs of infection, like pain or redness and swelling. See your doctor if you suspect infection. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.**

patterns: How do you treat a sting?
Stings
What to do if you get a sting?
Which medicine should I apply for a sting?
How to remove a stinger?
responses: Remove any stingers immediately. Some experts recommend scraping out the stinger with a credit card. Apply ice to the site for 20 minutes every hour, wrapped in a towel. Taking an antihistamine such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl) or loratadine (Claritin) will help with itching and swelling. Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Motrin) for pain relief as needed. Wash the sting site with soap and water. Placing hydrocortisone cream on the sting can help relieve redness, itching, and swelling. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.**

patterns: How to remove splinters?
How do I cure splinters?
What to do if I have splinters?
How do you bring a splinter to the surface?
How to get a splinter out?
responses: 1. Soak the area in Epsom salts. Dissolve a cup of the salts into a warm bath and soak the affected area. Alternatively, apply Epsom salts to a bandage and leave it covered for a day. 2. Soak the affected area in olive or corn oil, or white vinegar for 20-30 minutes. If the splinter is visible, use sterilized tweezers to remove it. Clean the area with soap and water after removal. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.**

patterns: How do you treat a sprain?
What to do if I get a sprain?
Which cream should I apply if I get a sprain?
Which medicine should I apply if I get a sprain?
How to treat a sprained ankle?
responses: Use an ice pack for 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours while awake, wrapped in a towel. Compress the sprained area with an elastic bandage until swelling stops. Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB) or acetaminophen (Tylenol) can help manage pain. Elevate the sprained area. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.**

patterns: How do you treat a strain?
What to do if I get a strain?
Which cream should I apply if I get a strain?
Which medicine should I apply if I get a strain?
How do you diagnose a strain?
Is heat or ice better for a pulled muscle?
responses: Rest, ice, compression, and elevation can be used to treat strains. Avoid using the muscle for a few days. Apply ice for 15-20 minutes, wrapped in a towel, immediately after injury. Compress the affected area with an elastic bandage. After 3 days, either heat or ice may be helpful. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.**

patterns: How do you treat a mild fever?
What to do if I get a mild fever?
Which medicine should I take if I get a mild fever?
Fever
How to reduce a fever?
responses: Drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated. Dress in lightweight clothing. Use a light blanket if you feel chilled. Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB). Get medical help if the fever lasts more than five days. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.**

responses: Use a humidifier or vaporizer. Drink plenty of fluids. Place a warm, wet towel on your face. Saline nasal spray or drops can help. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. patterns: How do you treat gas problems?

responses: Replenish body fluids. Avoid antidiarrheal drugs, laxatives, or pain medication unless prescribed. Antacids may help. Eat non-spicy meals. Seek medical help if conditions persist. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.**

responses: Move away from the snake. Lie down with the wound below the heart. Keep still. Cover the wound with a loose bandage. Remove jewelry. Do not attempt to suck out the venom. patterns: How to give CPR?
What to do in CPR?
What steps to take in CPR?
How to help a drowning person in CPR?
responses: Place hands on the center of the chest. Push down at least 2 inches. Do chest compressions at 100-120 per minute. Check for breathing. Call emergency services immediately. **This information is for general knowledge and first aid guidance only, and does not constitute medical advice. Always consult with a qualified healthcare professional for diagnosis and treatment.**
